title: ROBO R1 Dual Fan Duct Cooling System

description.text:
UPDATE
I have just made a new change to the fan duct so than when screwed into place they sit further from the build plate. I noticed that the corners had a possible tendency to touch the plate. May need some filing to fit.

Part cooling upgrading for printing better bridges and overhangs. This is a remix of the TechsupportGo's mount with some minor changes to the design, and to the print itself.

The REAR shroud has been cut shorter so that none of the plastic comes into contact with the heater block. (on my printer it is the front shroud, because of how it have it setup...) As a result your part is not slowly destroying itself by melting on the heater block as you print, especially with high temp filaments.

See instructions for printing recommendations and hardware list.

Ok for the prints.

The 40x10 part is the most important to look out for, I printed it NOT out of PLA but out of PET+. ABS or nylon would be good too. This part comes into contact with the heat sink so it will have to cope with high heats, too much heat to print out of PLA. Print it on a 50% infill with 3-4 shells.

Each of the different shrouds CAN be printed from PLA. I used 3 shells on 50% infill.

SCREWS
You will need four 1 inch #6 sheet metal screws, and four of the exact same screws except 1.25 inch rather that 1. You can find them at your local hardware store.

Fans
2 12v 40x40x20mm case fans. You'll want some that will reach a speed 8200-9000 RPM. I got mine on amazon here....

http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B006ODM76C?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s01

ASSEMBLY
Should be self explanatory. You will have to take off the existing fan carriage, and replace it with the part you're printed. See my pictures for reference BUT NOTE; my heater block is turned 180 degrees which will not be the case on your printer. So on your printer (given the heater block is in its stock position) the longer shroud duct will go on the front and the shorter one on the back. If you're reading this and it makes no since, you should understand as soon as you're putting it on the printer.

OPTIONAL
For a more finished look you can also purchase two fan gills to place over the open ends of the fans.

title: iPhone Bracket for My Pickup Truck

description.text:
I love 3D printing.  I needed a phone mounting bracket for my 1996 Ford Ranger pickup, so I designed exactly what I wanted.  I suspect there are not too many '96 Ranger owners out there, but I still thought I would share my low-brow approach in case it is useful to anyone.
It works like this: the mounting bracket slides into a cubby hole on the dashboard.  Luckily the cubby hole has some small 1/16th ledges a little over an inch back.  The bracket has small steps that catch on the ledges. The extra length of audio cord is held in a slot behind the bracket.
The gap between the bracket legs is created by snapping out the center section, where the leg thickness tapers down to one filament thick and then expands back out (see line drawing below left).

If you too can use this bracket, you need a newer pickup truck. Feel free to modify it to meet your needs. 
Good printing!

description.text:
These will really help seal up the build space when printing ABS/

The covers swivel to allow them to be closed with printing ABS, and open when printing PLA. They don't need to be removed and snap into place.

Do not scale.

Once both pieces are printed flex the flapper to help it go into the swivel holes. If you push hard enough they will snap it. Its easier to just flex the flapper a little.

The flapper needs to spin a few times before it spins easily.

I printed them in PLA

Both pieces take about 90 total and I used 7% fill.

title: Prusa I3 10MM X Carriage Assembly With Tensioner

description.text:
Redesigned mounts using set screws to fasten 10MM smooth rods.
Much more sturdy than stock 8MM design. Takes 370MM x 10MM
smooth rods. I've added my J-Head and extruder motor mount and an X belt tensioner to the X Idler and an adjustable Z endstop holder. The Idler mount now has "Smooth Rod" through holes so that the rods can be slid out to access the center section without disassembling the printer. The slot in the Idler for the belt bearing screw has a break out panel that must be snapped off before assembly. Filament tension arm uses a 14mm bearing. J-Head mounting holes are 6-32. Mounting holes in center block are 8-32. Set screw holes for 10mm rods are 6-32 (top) and 4-40 (bottom).

Uses (2) 19mm x 55mm x 10mm and (2) 15mm x 45mm x 8mm
bearings. Do not over tighten the set screws.

comments.text:
Hey Puny, I've gone into Rhino and exported the entire 10mm x carriage assembly in IGES for you. It includes my hotend mount for my Prometheus v2 hotend. The center section has holes for it but you can fill them in as needed for your setup. Send me your email address and I'll shoot it off to you. Keep in mind that the idler mount has through holes for the x rods and set screws allow the rods to be slid completely out through the idler so that you can access your center mount without tearing your whole machine appart. So make sure after printing that you sand the rod holes so rods slip through easily. Hope it works well for you. Brian
([email protected])

title: Prusa i3 Direct Extruder with X carriage for E3D hotend, full cooling.

description.text:
Yet another design of extruder for Prusa i3. X carriage is compatible with other style direct extruder with NEMA17 stepper.

Key Features:

  • Compact and lightweight X carriage, no zip-tie LM8UU bearing mount.
  • Quick filament change locking lever.
  • Robust cooling with 40mm fan shroud and 52mm blower nozzle.

BOM:
--

  • MK7 extuder gear 10.5mm effective diameter
  • Spring 5mm ID
  • 624ZZ bearing
  • E3D hotend V5, (the long one/clone)
  • 40mm fan
  • 52mm blower
  • 3pcs LM8UU bearing

Hardware:

  • 8pcs M3 x20mm socket head screw, 3 for NEMA17 stepper, 1 for locking lever, two for E3D clamping. 1 for blower top mount, 1 for extruder spring tensioner.
  • 1pcs M3 X6mm flat head countersunk screw for top right NEMA17 mount.
  • 1pcs M4 X16mm screw for 624zz bearing mount
  • 6pcs m3X12mm, 5 pcs for 40mm fan/shroud, 1 pcs for blower nozzle support
  • M3 nuts and washer as necessary, Fan mounting holes on printed parts are intentionally designed to be smaller, such that they can be mounted by M3 thread tapping in the hole without nuts.

Design considerations:

  • X carriage is designed with thin wall structure for rigidity yet not over constraining LM8UU bearing. Two bottom LM8UUs are responsible for X-Z plane load, while top LM8UU holds up for Y.
  • An eccentric locking lever is added to facilitate filament handling.
  • Minimum fastener usage.
  • No zip-tie.
  • Robust cooling fan mount.
  • No constrains for NEMA17 motor length so high torque stepper is highly recommended.
  • Top LM8UU bearing holder have reduced stiffness to accommodate X carriage rod misalignment.
Parts can be printed with minimum needs of support. Brim is highly recommended for X carriage, around the LM8UU bearing holder as to avoid and wrap which can lead to LM8UU misalignment.

author: beyondwind

description.text:
This is a five-cup kendama; having four cups atop the handle in a "plus" format.

Note that typical 5-cup kendamas have the cups offset (due to the way the wood must be manufactured); this kendama has them all in the same plane.

This is a remix of my "Kendama V2" — this thing only contains the new parts (two handle halves, and a connector bar). You must download the cups, tip and ball from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:833183

Print the top & bottom handle halves (they're different due to the angle of the hole for the string), and the "coupler bar".

Then print two each of the "big cup" and "little cup" as well as one "tip" and "ball" from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:833183.

The string holes will probably need to be drilled out.

When assembling the handle halves and coupler bar, make sure the string hole in the coupler bar is properly oriented to match the string holes in the handle halves.

Projects the sound from your phone outwards -- works very well. Phone speaker should be on the bottom of the phone (or flip over your phone). Works for all smartphones tried so far.

title: Modified Prusa I3 single motor Z mod complete

description.text:
This is a mod to use a single motor for Z to prevent the X axis from becoming untrammed due to normal 2 motor systems becoming out of sync. It uses Cupcake Z parts.
Specifically:
2 each 5mm bore GT2 2mm pitch 36t pulleys (SDP-SI)
4 each 624ZZ bearings as idlers (Ultimachine)
1 each Cupcake Z belt GT2 2mm pitch, 6mm wide, 424 teeth (SDP-SI)
3 each 5x11x4mm flanged bearings for the 5mm Z screws (VXB)
1 each 5mm to 5mm flex coupler (Adafruit)
8 each 4mm bore fender washers (Ultimachine)
8 each regular M4 washers (Ultimachine)
4 each M4 x40mm capscrews (Ultimachine)
4 each M8 nuts used for spacers (not shown in picture, Ultimachine)
2 each M5 standard washers (between pulleys and top bearings (Ultimachine)
4 each M4 nylock nuts (Ultimachine)
Also, the stock Z threaded rod would have been
5 mm for Z- Axis: 2 x 12"
However, they should now be around 13 inches for the motor side and 15 inches on the right side since we don't use a motor and coupler so it needs to go all the way down into the lower bearing support on that side. The square "fake" motor plate is what also holds the right Z smooth rod. but the cutout allows for locknuts to rotate with the 5mm threaded shaft.

Sorry, the picture doesn't show the Z smooth rods caps (last minute addition). The picture also doesn't show the M8 nuts spacing the 624 bearing idlers up and the pulleys need switched hub down, then M5 washer, then flanged bearing. The Z motor would remain on the left hand side as normal. The right hand side has a different motor bracket sized for another flanged bearing. The bearing should go in on the bottom side as should any lock nuts on the M5 threaded shaft to keep the rod in tension, not compression. More detailed finally assembly pics to come. The idea is to ensure the X axis always stays 90 degrees to the Z once initially adjusted. The original 2 motor design made it impossible to move the Z axis by hand when required without messing up tramming in X axis. One less motor and far less stress on the poor little Pololu than trying to drive 2 motors.
Also, could allow for oldschool knob or crank on the Z axis for manual adjustments. Maybe this modified for 5mm threaded rod http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1359
Note, it might be a good idea to leave the 5mm Z threaded rods a little longer for crank mods. It's easy to cut, it's hard to add back.
SDP-SI.com
36t pulleys 2 each Part Number: A 6Z51M036DF0605 $6 each
GT2 6mm wide belt Part Number: A 6R51M424060 $8
Ultimachine.com
624 bearings 4 each https://ultimachine.com/content/624zz-bearing $1.25 each
Big fender washers 8 required comes in pack of 15 https://ultimachine.com/content/fender-washer-pack-15 $1.49
regular M4 washers 100 pack https://ultimachine.com/content/m4-washer-pack-100 $1.99
M4 x40mm 4 required 50 pack is https://ultimachine.com/content/m4-x-40mm-socket-head-cap-screw-pack-50 $8.49 --maybe buy local?M4 nyloc nuts 4 required 100 pack https://ultimachine.com/content/m4-nylok-pack-100 $3.59
Assuming you have 4 larger M8 nuts or something to use as spacers on the M4 capscrews to space up the idler bearing blocks. VXB
Requires 3 each 5x11x4mm flanged bearings
http://www.vxb.com/SRCH.html?Store_Code=bearings&Search=5x11%2C4+flanged

comments.text: is there no way to make it work without the idlers? bolt on extra rod and link them directly perhaps?
comments.author: kizinfo

comments.text: I'm not sure I am even remotely understanding the question. The ENTIRE purpose is to link, VIA timing belt, the left and right Z axis leadscrews to ensure the X axis remains square and "level" while also reducing the system to a single motor. With a 2 motor system, nothing keeps them in "sync" when they are not enabled or powered. This means that during transport and even sitting still, it is possible for the motors to become out of perfect sync. Upon enabling, one motor might jump to the next step and that in turn makes the X axis not longer square to Z travel, also affecting what would look like bed leveling. By using a belt and mechanically connecting the leadscrews, the bot will always remain square and adjusted.
comments.author: kizinfo

comments.text: Further, without the idlers, the belt path runs right into the filament feed path of the extruder on the front. The Idlers also ensure the belt wraps further around the pulleys to ensure it's nearly impossible for the belt to jump a tooth on the pulleys without requiring extreme tension. Any variance from the belt path generally puts the belt at odds when the extruder is at the top of travel. I'm not sure where the rod comes into play? You could use a shaft drive to connect the 2 screws but that then requires right angle gear drives which are even more expensive. Not to mention, ensuring correct rotation between the 2 rods. The belt is not easily placed at the bottom side because it would interfere with the Y axis.
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: the principle is great, trying to see if there is a way to do it without the laser cut top. my question was, if the z screws could be extended in height, could they then be linked together directly without idlers? Although your point about belt wrap and tensioning would still likely apply, perhaps fouling could be avoided?
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: OK. so concern with just lengthening the 5mm threaded rods is, they are just 5mm threaded rods. The belt provides a side load to the shaft in order to rotate them. IF you make the rods longer and the pullleys are out at the ends, the last bearing where they are supported from side load is some distance from the pulley. This would result in the shaft bending or flexing, possibly causing the belt to skip teeth on the pullleys.  I'm just not seeing how your idea is workable. The fact you want to extend the rods but not have a plate between them just  is bad engineering. You simply are not accounting for the pull of the belt. I'll even admit that in my design, the 36t pulleys really should be flipped hub up so that the belt path is as close as possible to the bearings mounted in top plate. Doing so created a lot of interference with the screw heads and stuff so we flipped them and spaced the belt up, but from a technical standpoint, the thin threaded 5mm rods are flexing a tiny bit. This is why you don't really want to tension the belt too tight and why the amount of wrap is critical. More belt wrap means you can get away with less static tension.
comments.author: kizinfo

comments.text: Yes. Absolutely Yes. I think mechanically you are wright. Let me know if is working better. I notice that one engine will do the job better in this configuration. Thanks.
comments.author: chris77uk

comments.text: Or, you could simply wire the two motors in series.  If they're still getting out of sync at that point, you've got binding problems to solve.
comments.author: raldrich

comments.text: BTW, putting is series is bad, putting in parallel is bad. Parallel, each motor sees half of the current, but the trick there is, the poor A4988  or even the newer drivers max out thermally around 1.5A without serious direct cooling. So, each motor in theory gets about 0,75A max reliably in parallel. In Series, you now are doubling the inductance and therefore limiting the max speed. So either way, double motor is not ideal. You are either way below spec on torque because the driver cannot supply 2 motors worth of current (3A max), or you go in series as you have suggested and now have a very distinct and lower feedrate limit before torque drops off and you lose steps due to doubling the inductance. Then couple that with if you lost steps likely it's not exactly both sides and now your X axis is not square or trammed to the bed. Or, just use this, run a single motor at the full 1.5 A, not overheat the driver and not ever have to mess with aligning the gantry. Set it and forget it.
comments.author: raldrich

comments.text: No, totally missed the point. What happens when the machine is off? What happens when some kid decides to move 1 screw by hand? Yes, 2 motors work when they are constantly enabled until the end of time, otherwise, at some point you will power down and then all bets are off. It's one of those things, use the mod if you want to, ignore it if you don't understand why a person might want to use this.
comments.author: raldrich

comments.text: Any chance you could get a photo of that bottom-right motor mount that no longer has a motor attached to it?
comments.author: sgraber

comments.text: Sure, but it's not that tricky. The only difference is the hole size where the stepper was, was reduced to 11m to hold a 5x11x4 flanged bearing, the same like the top. Because the motor is missing, the 8mm smooth rod would fall through but there is a fake motor plate that covers the 8mm hole.
comments.author: sgraber

comments.text: Pics being added now. More to follow.

description.text: I needed a way to mount a laser to an L bracket for a lunchbox laser light show project (http://laserlunchbox.com/LunchboxLaser_08_kh.pdf). I designed it in OpenSCAD to fit the laser module I have, and to fit the 5/8" bracket I had. It's somewhat parametric though it has some issues when scaled outside the intended size. The mounting holes are teardrop shaped to facilitate printing, using a simplistic teardrop module I created (there are better teardrop modules on Thingiverse, but it is included for completeness). If the holes are an issue (they were for me), they can be commented out. It's designed with a small slit and tabs which can be clamped together with a M3 bolt, nut, and a couple washers.
Print.  Add bolt, nut, and washers.  Attach to whatever you want.

I needed a block and tackle to lift hay bales in my shed. I found this one here by Mysabre73:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:963214
but it was too big for my 150x150 Printrbot Simple. I got it printed at 90% but figured I'd rather have 608 bearings on the pulleys so it ran a little more freely and lasted longer.

So I whipped up some OpenSCAD files and got it done.

Update 1: I found out how to join circles by tangents rather than direct to a perpendicular radius. Version 2 of the .scad and .stl files use the 'hull' function. I haven't printed this version yet, but it should be neater.

I sliced all STL files with Slic3r, using 4 shells and the new 3D honeycomb infill at 30% for strength. The long parts must be rotated 45 degrees if you only have a 150mm (6 inch) bed.

The bolts I used are 6mm x 50mm high tensile. The holes in the shells and the 608 bearings have an ID of 7mm so I used a 1mm sleeve to make it snug. A 1/4 x 2 inch bolt may work for the imperialists.

6mm abrasion resistant rope finished it off.

description.text:
This is the case for a mini volt meter and momentary contact button
switch. I have a lithium battery in a motorcycle and found lithium
batteries get low, they just do not start. I added this volt meter to
monitor the condition of the battery. It's mounted by zip ties to a tube
handle on the motorcycle. Pressing the button on the top of the case
displays the voltage of the battery.

Components:
Mini 2-wire Volt Meter (3.2 – 30 VDC) from Adafruit
https://www.adafruit.com/products/460

Tactile Switch Buttons (6mm tall) from Adafruit
https://www.adafruit.com/products/1490

Two small screws

Printer Settings:

PLA (Black), 0.1mm Layer Height (First Layer 0.2mm), 20% infill, no support material, 190 degrees (195 degrees first layer).

Construction:

Note, this is a small enclosure, so putting this together may take
several test fits before final assembly. Take your time, it will all fit!

Test fit and file openings and drill holes if needed. Test fit the screws. Cut the two unused contacts of the switch, straighten the two
contacts and give them an outward bend. Start with the case back
and put the two contacts into the two outside holes in the switch
mounting brace and press the switch into place. Route the wire to
the switch, cut the red wire and connect and solder the cut ends to
the two contacts of the switch. The wires exit the case through holes in the back of the case. Move the wire and switch contacts out of
the way and put the case together. Two screws hold the case
together. The screws go in through the bracket, then into the case. Two zip ties can be put through the slots in the bracket to secure the meter to a frame tube. The meters wires connect to the battery.

The 123D Design file is included so you can make modifications to
the case or bracket for your application.

Press and hold the button on the top of the case to read the battery
voltage.

description.text:
Clip this to your car visor and it will hold your sunglasses.

After the one I use broke, I decided to make my own improved version.

One thing to note is that this item requires secondary materials and assembly, including some 14-gage spring-steel wire (1095 or the equivalent) for the visor-holder wire, a short length of 12-gage wire for the hinge, and some neoprene rubber glued in to hold the sunglasses in the center.

All parts have been modeled separately to facilitate building and dimensional guidance.

I assume one day that 3D printers will be able to print foamed-rubber, and various metals, and then something like this would a one-shot production, but for now it's an assembly.

My major innovative change is to improve the durability and strength of the clasp, which is the major failure point of the device, through use of a flexure-based design and copious use of filets which avoids sharp 90° corners that act as stress-concentrators, and tend to be where breaks propagate.

Here's an example of this kind of clip that you might find in any corner gas-station:

http://i.imgur.com/n5hzvmp.png

Here are the parts for my coil winding machine. I haven't developed it further for many months now, but I hope somebody might get some inspiration from the design.

The main winding motor is an L293D-driven servo motor (with electronics removed). The linear guide has a NEMA 11 stepper for driving the wire, driven by a standard pololu stepper driver. The wire length counter is based on a QTR-1A https://www.pololu.com/product/2458 reflectance sensor. The same reflectance sensor is found on the winding turn counter. Actually it's a RC version which has been converted to an analog version. The resistor is a different one so one might have to change the analog values in the code when using original pololu sensors. A strip of white tape reflects the IR light (4 on the wire length counter).
A standard 16*2 lcd shows the options and progress and settings are entered with a rotary encoder. Main processor is an arduino pro mini. All connections can be derived from the Arduino code (.ino file). There are some less common ball bearings: 2x 626ZZ and a tiny 4mm inner and 8mm outer diameter one on the wire guiding/length counter wheel).
The code is still in an early stage, I coded in just enough precision to be able to wind the axial flux alternator coils which worked reasonably well.

Minions are different, and so are we. So, here's how to become a minion with just the right look, as well as fit.

Configure you own goggles at Minion Goggles

First, measure the distance between the eye pupils. Be sure the person is looking away while measuring. Then, measure the distance across the cheek bones. These help determine the size of the glasses. Finally, measure the flat area of the forehead. This determines the roundness of the head, and helps to fit the glasses properly to the face.

Second, measure the size of the nose, both height and width (across the nostrils). And then guess the angle of the nose, starting at the apex of the bridge to the tip of the nose. Finally, measure the offset of nose from the center of the pupils, moving the starting point (sellion) up or down depending on the position of the nose. Hint: Children don't have a large nose bridge, so the starting point should be lowered by 5 mm or more.

Third, purchase some nice elastic band for the strap, then put in those dimensions. Hint: Add 1 mm to both width and thickness.

FYI: The uploaded STL file is fixed, unchangeable, and for an adult that has a face in the 50 percentile.

FYI: Scaling of the design is possible but strap sizes, face profiles, etc will also be scaled. A better solution is to configure the goggles for the person.
Configure you own at Minion Goggles

title: Cane / Staff - Star Wars Obi-wan Kenobi Lightsaber Style

description.text:
SEE COMMENTS: I'M TRYING TO IMPROVE THE MODEL - WIFE KEEPS BREAKING IT, AND I'VE ADDED LIGHTS...

We needed a cane for my wife, so taking a page from Peter Mayhew, we decided to build a lightsaber cane! It's an Obi-wan Kenobi based one because that's what we had the best plans for, though we have some optional extra parts

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h4scLdEmIqs has video of the newest one!

Sort of a random thing, but if you like my stuff please check out my Lego R2-D2's blog at http://L3-G0.com or L3-G0's YouTube, and please tweet of facebook a link to his page, every visitor helps!

There's a PDF with just junk in the files....

OBI-WAN LIGHTSABER CANE / STAFF

This is an Obi-Wan style lightsaber cane, ala Peter Mayhew, except his is a lot longer, and different. I modified this when it was clear my wife would occasionally need her cane after hip surgery, yet we wanted to do fun convention things.

WARNING:

This design currently is split in the middle of the handle. You may want some serious glue there for safety, especially if the user puts a lot of weight on it. I might try to address that in a future revision. Inspect often, you don’t want to use it if it’s falling apart!

Additional Parts:

• You’re gonna need a ¾” acrylic rod, preferably a translucent blue.
• You’ll need a ¾” cane/crutch type foot.

Printed Parts:

A – Pommel
BC – Combined Lower Gear and Clamp
(See below for optional B & C1/C2 variations)
D1 – Lightbulbs
(See below for optional D2 Circuit Board variation)
E – Switch (Short or Long)
F – Pin (May need different sizes or trimming, or without supports)
G – Buttons
H – (unused at the moment)
I – Grenade
J – Flywheel
(See below for optional Luke variations B & C)
K – Emitter Housing
L – Emitter Lens
(See below for optional Luke combined KL variation)

Preparation:

Cane Height:

This cane isn’t really designed to be adjustable. Have the user try a “normal” cane, preferably with a knob-type grip, to find a comfortable height. Once they’re happy with that, measure the length of their cane, you’ll need a rod almost that long.

The Rod:

You’re going to need a ¾” rod. They come in cast and extruded. I’m not sure, but cast might be preferable, it’s stronger… extruded might be more consistent diameter. Translucent blue might be nice, but whatever color makes you happy. It only needs to be 4-5” shorter than the person’s cane height. I’d chop off the bottom end after assembly so the user can try the height. It’s easier to make it shorter than longer!

Printing vs Rod Diameter:

Just to be annoying, not all rods are created equal. The 3D models were designed based on the first rod I have, and the tolerances of my printer. I’d be really amazed if those worked for you first try!

A ¾” rod is supposed to be 19.05mm. The model is designed at 19.20mm, which doesn’t allow a lot of room.

Try printing the flywheel part J first. The main handle is going to be much harder to get on than the flywheel (more surface area touching the rod). You want it to press fit. If it’s not fitting, scale the model a TINY amount, like 101% or 99%. Be careful of the fragile bits. Remember you can sand.

Your rod’s not going to be a uniform diameter. My flywheel was very tight in a bit, then loose, then tight again.

Printing

I printed everything with 20% infill, on MakerWare’s medium setting (0.2mm layer height). If you can, print the lightbulbs in clear filament, they look really good that way.

Make sure you get the temps right. Someone’s going to be leaning on this, you don’t want it to delaminate because the print wasn’t hot enough!

You may have to fiddle with the clip, I’ve had a hard time printing it well. It may need a raft to hold it or slow down the printer. They’re tiny, print a couple

Print the different pin sizes. You’ll want a tight fit.

Assembly

The odd thing is that when Obi-wan holds a lightsaber, the pommel is generally “down” and the blade “up”. Like a sword. So we’re kinda building it upside down.

A pair of rubber gloves can help hold the rod and whatever part you’re trying to move.

Look at the picture to see where the parts go.

• Print and test fit the flywheel (part J). If it you can’t get it on, make it bigger (101% maybe). If it’s loose, make it smaller (try 99%). If it’s really hard to get on then the hilt will probably be a disaster, so maybe try bigger.
• Test fit the Emitter Housing (K) and Lens (L). Sand or whatever to make them work.
• Take them apart (it can be hard to put them on the rod together)
• Put the Emitter Lens on the rod, facing down toward the floor.
• Put the Emitter Housing (K) on the rod. The handle/pommel side should be about 13cm or 5” from the end of the rod.
• Add the flywheel (J), the ridge part goes up, towards where the pommel will be. There/s about a 9mm or 3/8” gap between the flywheel and the emitter.
• Press on the grenade (I). There’s a little lip which is where the rod seats, so put the rod through the other end. It should be difficult to install, you don’t want the rod falling out when someone’s using the cane! If it’s really hard (I had to slam mine on the floor), then don’t expect to get it off!
• Put the pommel (A) on the Lower Handle (B). This is removable but should fit snugly. If concerned you can glue it.
• One of those 1” LED lights will fit inside the handle/clamp area, the pommel can provide access. (But you’ll need a really light colored rod for that to work).
• The buttons go in the holes in the clamp. You may have to glue them.
• If you printed a separate clamp/handle, put the clamp on the lower handle, little button goes away from the pommel. (Though it’ll work backwards)
• Shove the grenade (I) into the clamp.
• Slight the lightbulbs (D1) (or circuit board) into the clamp.
• Insert the pin (F) from the button side. You want the pin to be fairly tight to hold the grenade tight.
• Slide the switch clip (E) over the pin end, the end goes toward the pommel. I had to clean mine a little with a hobby knife. Again you want this to be tight.
• Temporarily put the rubber cane foot on the bottom.
• Stress test the cane. If the grenade part is at all loose in the clamp consider a really good adhesive. You don’t want this to break when the user slips and needs it for balance!!!
• WARNING: Make sure everything is tight and can’t fall apart when someone puts a lot of weight on it. Apply glue if necessary. If uncertain DO NOT USE IT!!!
• Remove the rubber foot and cut the cane to the right length using appropriate tools and safety protection (goggles, etc). Err on the side of too long, you can always cut it again if need be.

Notes

Since the cane is upside down, the lightsaber parts are labeled backwards. The pommel would normally be on the bottom, yet it’s the top of the cane.

The clamps have different holder dimensions for either Obi-Wan style lightbulbs or stunt style circuit boards, see variations below.

Stunt clamps have each side narrower by 2.75mm, so if you wanted to put lightbulbs in one, then stretch it by 2.75mm on each side.

If you really want to print a pin without a support there’s a file for it.

Diameter of shaft is expected to be ¾” (radius 9.5mm)

Variations

The easiest way to make it yours is the color of the rod. I’ve also stuck some variant parts in the build in case you want to try something different

Alternate lower handles (consider gluing to clamp for strength)
B – Lower handle with a heatsink gear OR flat variation
C – Graflex Clamp, either the Obi-wan ANH version or variations for the Stunt lightsabers
D1 – Use lightbulbs for the C1 clamp
D2 – C2 clamps have the circuit-board appearance, us the circuit boards for that.
E – Long or short switches.
J – Luke ROTJ type flywheel, “C” is flat, “B” might need supports to print
KL – Luke ROTJ type emitter & Lens.

Note that I don’t have the rest of the Luke ROTJ style handle right now. The “lower handle/clamp” area is different, and the “grenade” part has a slightly different pattern. The pommel is probably close enough for most folks though.

Electronics Files:
You can skip the LED holder and Xmas_Saber.ino and FastLED.zip if you aren't doing the lights (see Electronics below)

Acknowledgements

This is based on the slightly modified Obiwan Lightsaber, which in turn is based off of Ultimaker’s complex lightsaber. Thanks for the model.

Main difference here is this one has a hole, it’s been reinforced somewhat, and parts have been combined to make it stronger. It’s also been tweaked a little where the original’s accuracy bugged me.

I also added the bajillion alternate parts.

Also using the FastLED library.

If you like my builds, follow me on Thingiverse, http://www.thingiverse.com/kresty and visit my Lego R2-D2 on YouTube – http://L3-G0.com has links.

I tweet sometimes @ShawnsLego. http://twitter.com/shawnslego and have a boring FaceBook account https://www.facebook.com/shawn.steele.988

It's more fun if it glows!

We all know this is more interesting if it glows!

The easy way is to drop one of those little LED flashlights in the handle. It's just about perfect for the 3 AAA ones, but some have knurled edges that make them slightly too big.

Advanced Lighting

For more advanced lighting I used an Arduino Nano attached to some 5050 SMD RGB LED's (like neopixels, but I bought a ton on ebay for something like .25 each). I hooked digital output 6 of the Arduino to the data in of the LEDs and used the attached sketch.

Power is trickier, especially at the new 90% long lightsaber (her original one was too long to work best as a cane). I ended up buying one of those spare power LI batteries in a kind of tubular case. Unfortunately it was a little too fat (& long), so I had to remove it from the case. The procedure was straightforward if you know what you're doing, but shorting the battery would be bad and my technique hacky so I'm not going to go into that here. Alternatives would be 4 AAA batteries.

If you have +5V it can go into the Arduino's 5V line, otherwise you'll have to put it in Vin if you have more volts. The WS2812B 5050 neopixel type LEDs need 5V, so they can be connected to the Arduino's 5V line. The Arduino can power 4 of them safely.

Make sure to connect the data out of the first LED to the data in of the next one, etc. There's a picture of it in the LED folder in the main pictures above. If the LED holder is too loose you might try the "small" version.

The Xmas_Saber.ino sketch needs the FastLED library. I zipped that up and it needs to go into your Arduino\Libraries folder. It was intended for Halawaliama's Xmas lightsaber, so you may want to kill the color changing code &/or program a different color.

comments.text: The innards of the latest update's electronics are painful - https://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/sets/72157675966670774 has pix of the guts.  We're working on trying to shrink some of them.
comments.author: kresty

comments.text: what did you use for the blade did you use clear filament or did you get a full size rod form somewhere I am trying to design a Saber for my son and want to make it as interchangeable as possible but I'm not sure how well the LED at only one end vs. LEDs the full length of the blade will look in a 3d printed clear blade but at the same time I don't want to have to outsource the blade to say acrylic or fiber optic?
comments.author: CAQB13

comments.text:
The blade is a 3/4" acrylic rod from a plastics shop. They actually aren't very expensive for a few feet.
We have LEDs at one end. Other people have ran a strip of LEDs down a tube instead of a rod. (but my wife needed a cane, so for strength a tube was ruled out).
Transparent filament doesn't really print clear, it prints more frosted (which might actually look good for this, but a rod or tube is way easier)
comments.author: CAQB13

comments.text: PS: I haven't finished the sound yet, but I ripped apart one of the toy lightsabers and it seems promising.
comments.author: kresty

comments.text: BTW, if you want to light it up, a colored rod may be too dark to light.  Our blue rod doesn't really work.  The clear works OK to light.  I was wondering about getting a clear rod and then dying the outside edge somehow but haven't tried that yet.  The thinking being that the light could still transmit down the rod since the middle would be clear, but not be filtered too much on the outside.

PLA is more resistant to acetone than ABS, so If you are washing your tubes with acetone, I would suggest you to use PLA.

author: Gadgetruud

description.text:
I made this from scratch using pictures as reference. I borrowed the worm gear model from Johann517's Spider Rover and modified it slightly. You can view the original design at:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:468872

This is the famous killer metallic sphere from the 1979 cult movie classic "Phantasm". If you haven't seen this horror film, then you must be living underneath a rock. You will need to print out two blades. The sphere has pre-made slots you can stick the blades into. You might need to file or trim the slots to make a good fit. I was thinking about casting a life size aluminum version and polishing it to a mirror shine. You could also use chrome spray paint and some clear coat. I would recommend using support material just to be on the safe side.
EDIT 05-16-2016: I cut the bottom half with the drill into two pieces for easier printing. Just glue the two bottom pieces named bottom_a and bottom_b to make up the bottom portion of the sphere. I used Zatoichi's make where he split the bottom drill part into two pieces as inspiration. Thank you.

Please do not use this model for commercial purposes.

comments.text: Looks awesome!!! That is very well done!
comments.author: Enterprisedavid

comments.text: thanks
comments.author: MustangDave

comments.text: I rewatched the 4 Phantasm films for the first time in decades recently and then a week later went to Fantastic Fest 2016 in Austin and saw the restored original and the premiere of the fifth and final Phantasm film, Phantasm: Ravager. Don Coscarelli and the whole crew (minus Agnus Scrimm who died recently) were there for the premiere and did a bunch of Q&A's, poster signings, etc. and then just hung out and talked to people. I talked to Don for a while and asked about the origins of the Cuda used in the film and then gave him a gentle ribbing about not using a Mustang. I'm restoring a 65 coupe right now :)
comments.author: A_Great_Future_in_Plastics

comments.text: That's awesome! I am very saddened by Angus Scrimm's death:( His role in the movie is what made the movie scary for the most part. He will be greatly missed. Even though I am a die hard Mustang fan, you got to admit, the Cuda is a pretty darn cool car. I used to have a 65 coupe I bought with no engine or transmission for 500 bucks about 11 years ago, never got around to restoring it so I sold it. I've owned 5 Mustangs, currently I have a true blue 2001 GT five speed, it almost looks like it rolled off the assembly line. Good luck on your restoration!
comments.author: A_Great_Future_in_Plastics

comments.text: We were watching Phantasm 2 last night and I searched Thingiverse out of curiosity and found your model. Excellent tribute to a great series of movies! Yes, I will be printing this, still trying to decide best way to display. Wife said to spirit glue to my forehead for Halloween would be the best way to display!
comments.author: rlgrady

comments.text: Thank you for the comment! I watched all the series and found out that Thingiverse didn't have anything related to the movie, so I decided to make my own! Make sure to post some pictures when you make it!

comments.text: Great design! I loved these movies growing up, and finally get to have my own sentinel! comments.text: Wow, thanks for the quick help! I'm going to try to print it out this evening, and hopefully have full build pics by next week!

comments.text: Thank you very much for the comment. I am glad you like it. I have not printed this out yet, but another person had the same trouble as you with the screw. He fixed it by splitting the bottom half into two pieces and printing the screw vertically. I will chop up the bottom half into two parts when I have time for easier printing. I would recommend using acetone and scrap ABS mix as glue and maybe for filler. I can't remember what I did with the screw, I know I changed a few little things about it to make it more movie accurate.

description.text: This spool holder was designed so you could have one or add as many as you want. The top ring was designed to have the cyder inserted only half way in and then pined this allows for a second cyder to be put on the other side.

print a top and bottom for each side you need then bolt them to each other.
Next print the cyder and pins. Insert cyder in to one ring then insert the square pin in top of ring. Place spool on cyder and then slide second ring on to cyder and then pin.

description.text: Test object for aligning surfaces.

A rock tumbler that requires 8 bearings (4 per unit) so you dont have friction,the tubes you need you can get in any hardware store,designed to fit either 40mm or 50mm tube/pipe,pvc tube does the job for me, all you need is the gearing,later on i will ad some gears to it,the bearings you get on ebay ABEC-5 608-ZZ,the center is 8mm,i used alu rods (dont need the pins if you go for rods).
basically,just downloading the face file,canister and lids,the rest you can design as you need (the adaptor for the pipe you wil use,its a minute job,will upload later also)
use rubber sealing for the lid spacing,to close the canister use a threated rod--IF one of the parts loads to small on plater,multiply it by 10 (scale)

UPDATED.
New housing allows you to use a motor holder housing,desgined for the ones from arduino (ebay,arduino motor) with diam of 26.
the housing can be connected with 2 8mm rods,the lenght is up to you to fit the gears.

New feauters.
removed gear system,replaced with pulleys,so you can adjust it to your need of speed or torque (in any matter,speed control) with not much work,just change motor pulley and done

Part of https://github.com/jonnor/projects/tree/master/bicycle

Status: Prototyping. Lower part fits OK, works as replacement for manual operation. Top parts needs designing.

WIP TODO

  • Design upper part. Two-way friction lever, or spring on one side?
  • May need to modify lower part, so that wire is supported when being pushed
  • Decide if wire ball goes on bottom or upper end
  • Test!

Vitamins needed

  • Bicycle gear wire and Bowden tube. ~1 meter

This spring I was on a short camping trip to Svalbard, 78 deg. north. Due to the danger of polar bears it is mandatory to take necessary precautions to avoid injury from attacks (that is injury to both bears and people). One of several necessary precaution is to set up tripwires around the camp. I made these that can be attached to the skis with duct tape. Setting up tripwires requires knowledge on the subject as they are useless if set up wrong, and very dangerous, no kidding.

THESE DO NOT PROVIDE ANY FORM OF SAFETY. THEY MAY ALSO CAUSE FIRES AND SERIOUS INJURY EVEN IF USED AS INTENDED.
.

These should be printed in high density as this is not where you would want to save on plastic.

Use non-elastic multi-filament fishing line for the actual trip wire.

Use stainless steel shackles in the corner holders to run the fishing line through (you could probably strap the shackles directly to the skis without the holders).

Use a partly unthreaded screw in the hole going trough the holder above the hole for the spool axle to lock the spool.

If you can't figure out the rest you probably should go for some commercial product with a manual. Setting up tripwires requires knowledge on the subject as they are useless if set up wrong, and very dangerous, no kidding.

THESE DO NOT PROVIDE ANY FORM OF SAFETY. THEY MAY ALSO CAUSE FIRES AND SERIOUS INJURY EVEN IF USED AS INTENDED.

comments.text:
What a great idea have been looking at these signal launchers for awhile now. And hadn't really thought of any other use than an emergency signaling device. I hadn't put the idea together myself for using bear bangers. Thank you for your great idea the black bears are getting pretty brazen in their interactions with people where I canoe in northern Ontario I am going to add this to my gear. This should help to keep myself and the bears a bit safer, than just me and my winchester defender that I have carried in the bush as a bear deterrent for years now.
One quick question do you recommend using one launcher pen on a single line surrounding your camp or 4 launcher pens and lines to box in your campsite? I'm thinking at least 2 are going to be necessary for this.
comments.author: ThatEmuGuy

comments.text:
Hi
If the corner posts are rigid I use a pen in one corner and a line all round the camp with stainless shackles in three corners. However I use two lines at different hight and put the pens in opposite corners. Always testing that they release as intended before loading the pens (dont load them with tension on the wire). When hiking in polar bear country we keep food and utensils in closed containers outside the perimeter. It is a good idea to keep it close to the lower pen at the side of the release pin to increase the chance of it releasing if a bear should take interest.
comments.author: ThatEmuGuy

comments.text: Booby traps are a felony.
comments.author: shorttyd

comments.text: This on the other hand is a tripwire. In some places it is a felony not to use them.
comments.author: shorttyd

comments.text: I agree that I have no XP in this subject and should seek a commercial one with manual if I need one of these, but as someone who camps (not in bear country usually), what exactly does this do? Is it merely to alert you to the presence of a 4 legged intruder or activate something when tripped?
comments.author: IVIUPPET

comments.text:
Please do not misunderstand me. I am not trying to be arrogant, but there are safety issues hence the comment on manuals.
It is a tripwire to set up a perimeter around the camp. If tripped it should fire a slightly modified signal pen with a flash-bang cartridge (it will usually be tripped by a forgetful fellow camper). The flash-bang will hopefully scare off any dangerous game or at least alert you to its presence and give you time to take action. It is only one of several precautions needed when camping in some areas. The signal pen could of course be changed for some type of trigger to activate something else, but then it would probably be easier to make it from scratch.
comments.author: IVIUPPET

comments.text: I agree that I have no XP in this subject and should seek a commercial one with manual if I need one of these, but as someone who camps (not in bear country usually), what exactly does this do? Is it merely to alert you to the presence of a 4 legged intruder or activate something when tripped?
comments.author: IVIUPPET

comments.text: It doesn't seem that there is much that can burn there. I would love to build one for the hell of it, but around here it would not be to scare off bears as much as people jumping over my walls, but for everyone's safety I do believe its in my and all my fingers best interest to not build one. But it is one of the coolest tings Ive seen..
comments.author: Redsalamander

comments.text: It should be pretty safe from fire using it on snow, but you could always trip over one of the poles and fire a flashbang in to the tent, or in a window in your case. That could be ...interesting.
comments.author: Redsalamander

title: MVS MV1FZ Consolized - The 3d Printing version!

description.text:
So, i'm a big fan of arcades and SNK, i have a bunch of MVS boards lying around for consolization, since the most painful process is building the case, i have decided to disclose the designs that i'm making so people can iterate and make their own consolized mvs boards!

This case is aimed to fit the MV1FZ board version, as you can see its not finished, final designs are due to people acceptance and some free time on my part.

This print is optimized for low volume printers, but if you are printing this on anything other than pla, expect heavy warping on the edges.

Have fun, and if you make one, please post a picture!

Notice: This is a WIP, i mean HEAVLY, things might not fit at all on non SNK bootleg boards.
Print each part and secure with the locker and some instant/epoxy glue.

title: SMD Reels for various tape widths

description.text:
Hello, these are reels for a pick and place machine. I bought a PNP recently and had lots of SMD/SMT parts around that were not on reels.

I've tested them on the following printers: Replicator 2, Replicator 2X, Makergear M2, FlashForge Creator Pro.

The parts are labeled by internal dimension, i.e. the distance between the reel halves. So, pick the reel appropriate to the width of your SMD tape. Print out two of these parts and screw them together with #2 screws. Sheet metal screws like these work great:

https://www.boltdepot.com/Product-Details.aspx?product=9862

See them in action:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JyzlKQu38zA

author: flamtapgt

description.text:
A 3D printer based on the Cobblebot kit or OpenBuilds parts that is not over-constrained - smooth motion with minimal adjustment.

I'm printing now!

The name Cobblebot is the property of Cobblebot Inc. This work uses the kit of parts provided by them for a "Basic", but is radically different from their design.

I'm working on a modified build for the Cobblebot or OpenBuilds parts that will get it closer to an exactly constrained system (and much less sensitive to rail alignment). The target is a 15" cube build volume. Please note that there are both English and Metric versions of most of these drawings. If you get them plasma cut, use 1/8" steel; it cuts REALLY well. If you get them laser or waterjet cut, use whatever you want. They 3d print acceptably, but the end result is kind of floppy; I don't recommend it, but I did try it during my (many) rounds of testing.

Actual motion range:
X: 16" (which means that I can get BOTH heads to move over a 15.2" build area)
Y: 15.5"
Z: 17.5" with a little Y restriction on the front
16.75" for full Y travel

This weekend I assembled version AA of the Mad Scientist (whoops... Engineer) Bot. It is designed to be exactly constrained; no more than one thing controlling each degree of freedom (X, Y, Z, Theta, Phi, and Psi). With no actuators on it, I can grab the extruder carriage rail and wave it around (up and down, in and out) completely freely; WITH NO ADJUSTMENT! That's right, NO tweaking of rail alignment at all! Assembling the frame was amazingly fast!

I'm getting version AD cut today; it deals with mounting motors, belts and end stops. More bulletins to come!

The way it works is there are two Z assemblies, each controlled by a lead screw. Each of them has a long bearing on the front corner post that handles X, Y, Phi, and Psi. A pair of wheels runs on the left and right flat surfaces of the back corner post and controls Theta rotation, but NOTHING else. Z is controlled by the lead screw. The Y carriage has a long bearing on the left horizontal rail that controls X, Z, Theta, and Phi. The other end of the X rail has a pair of bearings running on the flats of the right hand horizontal rail that deals with Psi. I have set the Y drive up where it can either be driven from one side only (the side with the carriage), or driven on both sides using a long 5mm shaft across the front; I'll experiment to see which one I like better. Finally, the X motion is very similar to the stock extruder carrier, except that I moved the extruders really close together and provided a proper belt attachment. The extrusion volume should be close to a 15" cube.

Sorry, I didn't take any photos yet; too excited building!

I did a LOT of tapping the ends; this is a RADICALLY stronger/stiffer connection, if you are willing to do some drilling and tapping. The best choice for tapping the ends is a "gun tap" that pushes the chips ahead of it. McMaster http://www.mcmaster.com/#2703a73/=ymv413 is a good choice.

OK, I assembled rev E night before last (Rev F is going together tonight).

Big stuff:
Optimized all the plates (after initial fitup on AA)
Added motor, idler, and belt attachments
Added the ability to mount the hot ends UNDER the X carriage
Moved everything down to get the hot end to reach the bed
Created Z fittings with two different lowerings (to accomodate those of you that didn't buy 3/8" thick Aluminum beds)
Designed a bed
Designed an insulation holder for the bed

Lessons learned from Rev E:
Corner blocks DO NOT ensure your rails are rotated square to the other rails!
My planned end stop locations interfered with stuff
The belts are kind of short
Parts of the Y ran into the base
My X rail was hard to install
I didn't buy enough idler mounts
The power supply requires moving one of the bottom 20x60 beams over 20 mm

The AG revision is designed, now to get it cut...

Lots of rounds of cut/print, and try... I'm hoping revision AK is the magic one!

I got my Keenovo heater/temperature controller installed this weekend onto my 3/8" thick Aluminum build plate (I know, excessive).
Dang that thing heats fast! When I set it for 40C, I could feel the silicone heater warm up in 1 or 2 seconds! It got to temperature and overshot 2 degrees C in perhaps 10 seconds. The plate, of course, has a lot of catching up to do.

In my "mad scientist/engineer" mode, I couldn't resist adding instrumentation ;-) I have four miniature wire thermocouples set at center, 50, 100, and 150 mm radius and a separate thermistor. I insulated the base plate with Kapton tape, put down the sensors, added another layer of Kapton, then a layer of Copper tape over them for interference protection. I have also designed an insulation retainer for this plate. I promise that I will take some measurements on how even the heating is!

I test fit 3d printed AK version plates this morning; I think I have it now! Mwa-ha-ha-ha!

Ok, AK got the belts almost right, and got the X endstop to work BUT, the Y endstop hit the top frame and the X belt idler hit the top frame. Argh! On to AN and AM.

OK, Revision AP for the frame plates is the winner! The motions line up nicely, run smoothly without adjustment, the belts work, and the limit switches work! Time to start wiring! That, and make the magic stepper motor to shaft connector WITH a timing pulley on it.

The cable chains came out well! Cutting and extending EVERY single wire... Ugh. There is a photo of what the series Z motor harness needs to look like, in case you want to make it the way I did. You can check your Z wiring by shorting each phase and turning one screw to lower the gantry; the other side should lower too. It will NOT raise this way; not enough power output! The motor you are turning acts as a generator and drives the other one. I hope to plug everything in tonight.

Key item: I un-soldered one side of D1 on the RAMPS board to isolate the Mega from +12. I will use a regulator to feed the Mega with 9 Volts to bring down the power dissipation.

Another tip: my prox sensor produces an inverted output. Took a while to diagnose!

I am printing now; the first try on a 20 mm calibration cube looks good!

I printed a test piece with the far side Y belt disconnected to see if that makes any difference in the prints. It BARELY makes any difference. I will put the belt back on, since I already have it in place, but its optional now!

The instructions are now in PDF format; thanks to Brian Lester and James Anthraper for their careful recording of builds #2 and #3!

Here's the master document:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1vYLTXMoXqMBRNg4-7-4rcp65SnHsG-HFZmTLoMi07yc/edit?usp=sharing

I have added an Excel sheet (and a PDF of it) that lists all of the hardware that you need to build this.
The plate identification and stuffing guide shows all of the plates with what goes in each hole and which side it goes on.

I've added a new build plate design; a skinny one for supporting a glass sheet. Stick your heater to the bottom of the glass, and then either binder clip or silicone the glass onto the build plate. The slot will clear the Keenovo heater leads and sensor.

comments.text: I mounted the Nimble Dual remote direct drive cold end on my WeldingRodBot this weekend, along with a new E3D Cyclops.  No complaints so far, although I lost about 40mm of build height (or alternately, 20mm of X axis) when allowing for the new drive cables to pass under the top of the frame.  It’s a fair trade for improved quality and reduced jamming.

description.text:
This is a simple belt tensioner that I made to replace my spring tensioners it is a single print and uses a cable tie to pull the belt shorter.

remixed_from.author: dintid
remixed_from.title: Modified and split Z-stage for Ultimaker 2 Aluminum Extrusion 3D printer

description.text:
Been making the Ultimaker 2 Aluminum Extrusion 3D printer at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:811271 and lacked the Heated bed cable clip, which the original builder had purchased I believe.

I used the files from the project to convert the cable clip to an STL we can print.

Make sure it is aligned flat.

There are 2 versions. The larger (in bytes) are direct conversion from IPT to STL and you need to make sure it is level.

The smaller version is imported to Tinkercad, reoriented and saved as STL.

I have printed both, and they look pretty much the same.

I used 100% infill as I do not like my pieces breaking apart.
Needed one a little bigger. Thanks for the solid file!

author: MAEA

description.text:
This upgrade of ToyREP will allow you to attach 40x40x10mm fans close to X, Y and E motor for better cooling and reliability. Fans may even let you use a bit higher print speeds. These models are prepared for 28BYJ-48 with four mounting holes but are also backward compatible with more common motors with two holes only.

Models should work, although I did not print them my self yet. My fans are already glued to similar positions, so I don't need this upgrade :D. And I don't have motors with four mounting holes at home either. They are marked as work-in-progress unless somebody will prove them working.

Change log

2015-09-02

  • Reuploaded X2_Rev2, as the original had some small issue in hole for M5 nut.
  • Prepared X1_M8 and X2_M8. These can use quicker M8 threaded rods for Z axis movement instead of slow M5.

2015-08-29

  • Uploaded revision for motors with four mounting holes.

2015-08-24

  • Reuploaded X1_Rev1, as the previous one had some issues.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.5mm nozzle, 0.25mm layer

Infill:

30% hexagonal

Notes:

Supports embedded where needed

It is pretty simple. Print these parts instead of the one attached to ToyREP. Use either Extruder_Rev2 for common motors with two mounting holes (looks better and aligned) or Extruder_Rev3 for motors with four mounting holes (dirty fix).

Fan mount

Add 3 pcs of 40x40x10mm fans and 6 pcs of 3x20-25mm wood screws. Attach each fan by two screws above every steper motor. Connect the fan cables either to free pins for endstops on RAMPS (than they will run at 5V from USB power socket) or directly to the 12V PSU.

Motor mount

Each motor will be attached by only two 3x13mm wood screews (already counted in BoM). For motor with two mounting holes use openings closer to the centre of the motor. For motors with four mounting holes use openings closer to the the blue plastic cap.

M8 threaded rods for Z axis movement

Print X1_M8 and X2_M8 instead of X1&2 for quicker Z movement. In BoM replace two M5x250mm threaded rods and two M5 hex nuts by two M8x250mm and two M8 hex nuts. The rest of the vitamins remains the same.

comments.text: whats the difference with the original files ? on the z axis mounts i only see more holes for mounting the steppermotor no fan holes altough it seems that the motors are deeper inside the mounts, so that would hinder the cooling, could you edit the naming ? the cryptic generated names are very confusing. very nice project though :) tnx
comments.author: Leitz

comments.text: Hi, thank You for your interest in the project. Z axis have no need for fan mount, as these motors do not have to be in break and they are moving only occasionally. Fans can be installed above X, Y and extruder motor. Other than that, there is possibility to use almost all types of 28BYJ-48 motors compared to original files, that are designed just for the most common kind. There is also possibility to use M8 threaded rods instead of M5 with new X axis files - in that case you need to update both sides of X axis.

author: MAEA

description.text:
This is a prop takedown sniper. Idea inspired by the Nemesis vanquisher.

Some of the files have not been added because they are unneeded. Like the lower parts, firing pin, and scope.(I did include the trigger itself)

You will need something to use for the barrel. (keep it shorter rather than longer, it is a tactical prop). You will also need rods for the sliding butt stock. And a steel pin for the trigger pivot.

Print the barreladt with 4 shells, i didn't include tolerances on that part because its permanent, so you'll need to sand it. Also the bolt pieces. I can't remember what I set those tolerances to, but It may not be enough.

comments.text: Ah the Vanquish! I stumbled upon that gun a few years ago.  From a conceptual/hypothetical design standpoint it would be cool if you could separate the lower from the upper/barrel assembly in addition to the stock! comments.text: Yea. the scope is pretty much in the drawing just for looks. Agreed though, hollywood has never heard of sighting in a scope. author: gtdeck13

description.text:
This is a multi-bobbin holder for electromagnetic coils, with a large hole in the center to allow a magnet-filled pushrod to move freely. It also has slots for holding a larger tube to form part of the linear actuator.

Object design in Autodesk Fusion 360 and downloadable at their [Gallery](https://fusion360.autodesk.com/projects/gluss-pusher-stator
-v24).

This is part of the Gluss Pusher project.

Freely reusable under Creative Commons Share Alike V 4.0.

(Note: This design does NOT have the bobbins correctly spaced at 1.5"s. This is a mistake, but probably anyone using it will want to change the geometry anyway.)

Object design in Autodesk Fusion 360 and downloadable at their [Gallery](https://fusion360.autodesk.com/projects/gluss-pusher-stator
-v24).

Printed with MakerBot Replicator 2 using PLA on "fast" mode. Gcode produced by Simplify3D. Requires supports due to overhangs. Printed vertically to make sure central hole was dimensionally correct. Required a small amount of sanding of central hole.

This could be useful as a starting point for someone making something different which requires holding two electromagnetic coils at precise distance.

Probably would be better printed in ABS, to tolerate coils getting hot. As designed right now, it is too heavy. Could use special holders to help organize the wires from the coils.

author: PrintTo3D

title: Rainbow G12.5mm f1.4 Lens to MFT Adapter

description.text: Adapter for the NIB Rainbow G12.5mm lens for micro four thirds cameras. Since this lens normally doesn't fit to standard c-mount adapters, I created a custom lens mount, which incorporates threads for focusing. For a 12.5 f1.4 lens it has pretty good sensor coverage :) Highres pics at http://www.flickr.com/photos/p1hde/sets/72157633909043803/

• Print rnbw12-5a.stl and rnbw12-5b.stl
  • Remove rubber-grip on the focus ring
  • Unscrew those 3 tiny screws underneath the rubber grip
  • Unscrew the focus-assembly
  • Fixate the rnbw12-5b.stl part on the lens (I drilled 3 holes and added M3 setscrews)
  • Mount rnbw12-5a on camera, screw in lens
    • If you want to edit the sorucefiles:
    Threads created with thread library by aubenc (slightly altered), imported to sketchup where the rest is desigend.

comments.text: Really nice design - thanks! I just printed two that I am planning to adapt to some old enlarging lenses. Will post pics once they're done.

author: omyomy

title: Pram frame clamp and parasol adapter

description.text:
Lost the clip for the parasol so I decided to make a compatible replacement. The idea was to make a sturdier clamp that would not "pop" off when re-positioning the parasol and could also be useful for attaching other things to the frame, for example cup, phone and bag holders.

The clamp took a little while to design in OpenSCAD due to the "funky" semi-elliptical tube frame.

Disclaimer: Obviously this clamp and parasol adapter has not gone through any rigorous testing so please use at your own risk. I don't want to be responsible for anyone getting fingers trapped or parasols falling off etc...

title: Fire Starter / Flint Sheath with keychain hole

description.text:
So my friend Danny got this cool Flint / Fire Starter from Amazon and thought it would be great to have on his key chain. Unfortunately the part that attaches to his key chain was way too big so I created this sheath for him which holds the Fire Starter perfectly without glue and sits perfectly on his key chain. I will add some pictures of the sheath in action later. I created this using 123 Design and have included the source files (along with the .stl files) if you'd like to change anything. Peace.

http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005XF2ITI?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00
Print it and jam your flint into it. The tension should hold it perfectly and you shouldn't need any glue or adhesive.

I created this Window Jam / Stop to keep my windows from opening and shutting violently when strong winds pass by our building. This is for large windows that open vertically. I put this thing into the opening in the window and it provides the support needed to keep the window open and prevents it from slamming shut. I used it most of the winter time and during the summer without an issue. I am not sure what the tolerance is as I have no way to test that but it has worked great for me and the rest of our office.

Open the window and slide the stop / jam down the side of the window. Make sure you are holding the window open the whole time. I made the handle long enough so that your fingers shouldn't be at risk but for safety reasons you would always have one hand on the handle of the window to prevent it from slamming shut on you. Once the jam / stop is in the window it should prevent the window from slamming shut again. To remove the jam, lightly tug on the window handle and slide the jam / stop out. It's pretty simple and I have included pictures in case i am not being clear.

Containers derived from thing:974854 - Snap Together Cube Puzzle - The containers are modular, "snapped" together from pieces. A container has four side pieces and a bottom piece. The side pieces are of two types, mix and match, the surfaces which snap together are identical. Two lid types are also provided. Multiple colors can be used and the containers made permanent with glue. OpenSCAD code is included.

The pieces fit best if the holes and spheres are upright for printing. The bottom and side 1 pieces can be printed lying on the build platform. Side 2 pieces stand on a point and support is needed. On my Replicator support can be restricted to rows along lines where faces meet by choosing 60 degrees for the support angle.

author: magiced

title: Raspberry Pi 2 case (vented with external screws)

description.text:
Raspberry Pi 2 case with ventilation and external enclosure screws.

Having an issue finding small enough screws for the mounting holes in the Raspberry Pi 2, I have moved the screws outside the case body and will be fixing the RPi down with foam mounting tape (3M command strips.) Additionally the screws no longer go all the way through the case, they just thread into the bottom piece. I didn't want to counter sink the screws on the bottom or add rubber feet to avoid scratching stuff.

Case screws together with M3-0.5 x 10 mm socket cap screws (can be found at Home Depot,) To attach the RPi to the bottom of the case I just used some small pieces of 3M command strip mounting tape.

I am using this for an HTPC so I have no need for the GPIO pins, and have removed them on my board. If you want to keep them you will need to trim them, bend them over or create a slot in the top piece to accommodate the extra height they require. I have included the .skp for easy editing.
